## R coding
For a demonstration of a scatterplot in R, see @fig-airq.

```{r fig-airq}
#| label: fig-airq
#| echo: true
#| eval: true
#| fig-cap: 'Scatterplot of Ozone vs. Temperature for the *airquality* data set'
#| fig-align: center
#| warning: false

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(airquality, aes(Temp, Ozone)) +
        geom_point() +
        geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE)
```

```{r sum-airq}
#| label: sum-airq
#| echo: true
#| eval: true
#| code-fold: false

summary(airquality)
```

## Python coding
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see @fig-polar. An R scatterplot is shown above in @fig-airq.

```{python fig-polar}
#| label: fig-polar
#| echo: true
#| eval: false

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()
```
